_**Land of the Lost**_ is a 2009 American [adventure](/wiki/Adventure_film
"Adventure film") [comedy film](/wiki/Comedy_film "Comedy film") directed by
[Brad Silberling](/wiki/Brad_Silberling "Brad Silberling"), written by [Chris
Henchy](/wiki/Chris_Henchy "Chris Henchy") and Dennis McNicholas and starring
[Will Ferrell](/wiki/Will_Ferrell "Will Ferrell"), [Danny
McBride](/wiki/Danny_McBride "Danny McBride") and [Anna
Friel](/wiki/Anna_Friel "Anna Friel"), loosely based on the 1974 [Sid and
Marty Krofft](/wiki/Sid_and_Marty_Krofft "Sid and Marty Krofft") [television
series of the same name](/wiki/Land_of_the_Lost_\(1974_TV_series\) "Land of
the Lost \(1974 TV series\)"). The film was theatrically released on June 5,
2009 by [Universal Pictures](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal Studios").

The film received generally negative reviews from critics and was a [box
office bomb](/wiki/Box_office_bomb "Box office bomb"), grossing just $68
million against its a $100 million budget. It received seven [Golden Raspberry
Award](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award "Golden Raspberry Award") nominations,
including [Worst Picture](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Picture
"Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture"), winning [Worst Prequel, Remake,
Rip-off or
Sequel](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Prequel,_Remake,_Rip-
off_or_Sequel "Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or
Sequel").

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Pompous [paleontologist](/wiki/Paleontology "Paleontology") Rick Marshall has
a low-level job at the [La Brea Tar Pits](/wiki/La_Brea_Tar_Pits "La Brea Tar
Pits"), three years after a disastrous interview with [Matt
Lauer](/wiki/Matt_Lauer "Matt Lauer") of
_[Today](/wiki/Today_\(U.S._TV_program\) "Today \(U.S. TV program\)")_ became
a [viral video](/wiki/Viral_video "Viral video") and ruined his career.
[Doctoral candidate](/wiki/Doctorate "Doctorate") Holly Cantrell tells him
that his [controversial theories](/wiki/Fringe_science "Fringe science")
combining [time warps](/wiki/Time_warp_\(science_fiction\) "Time warp
\(science fiction\)") and paleontology inspired her. She shows him a fossil
with an imprint of a cigarette lighter that he recognizes as his own along
with a crystal made into a necklace that gives off strong
[tachyon](/wiki/Tachyon "Tachyon") energy. She convinces him to finish his
tachyon amplifier and come help her on a seemingly routine expedition to the
cave where Holly found the fossil, which is in the middle of nowhere. With
cave gift shop owner Will Stanton they raft into the cave, where Marshall has
detected high levels of tachyons. He activates the tachyon amplifier,
triggering an earthquake that opens a time warp into which the raft falls. The
group finds themselves in a desert, filled with various items from many eras,
and without the amplifier. They rescue a primate-like creature, Cha-Ka of the
Pakuni tribe, who becomes their friend and guide.

The gang spends a night in a cave after surviving a meeting with a fast,
intelligent [Tyrannosaurus](/wiki/Tyrannosaurus "Tyrannosaurus") they nickname
"Grumpy", who stalks Marshall for calling him stupid. Marshall receives a
telepathic message begging for help and finds himself in ancient ruins. The
group encounters a race of [lizard men](/wiki/List_of_reptilian_humanoids
"List of reptilian humanoids") called Sleestaks before meeting the one who
sent Marshall the telepathic message, Enik the Altrusian. He explains that he
was exiled by the evil Zarn who is attempting to take over Earth with his
Sleestak minions, but Enik can prevent this if Marshall retrieves the tachyon
amplifier.

The group stumble upon a desert where many things from across time end up and
they encounter many [Compsognathus](/wiki/Compsognathus "Compsognathus"),
[Dromaeosaurs](/wiki/Dromaeosaurs "Dromaeosaurs"), Grumpy, and a female
[Allosaurus](/wiki/Allosaurus "Allosaurus"). The Allosaurus and Grumpy battle
it out over a previously killed ice-cream seller until they sense Marshall and
chase him. Marshall kills the Allosaurus with [liquid
nitrogen](/wiki/Liquid_nitrogen "Liquid nitrogen") and finds that the
amplifier was eaten by the Allosaurus. The amplifier is then stolen by a
[Pteranodon](/wiki/Pteranodon "Pteranodon") and taken to its nest. The group
arrives at the nest and Marshall lightly steps through the Pteranodon eggs to
retrieve the amplifier, but when he reaches it, it stops broadcasting the
soundtrack to Marshall's favorite musical _[A Chorus Line](/wiki/A_Chorus_Line
"A Chorus Line")_. When the eggs begin to hatch, Holly realizes that the music
was acting as a sort of lullaby keeping the baby Pteranodons asleep. Marshall,
Will and Holly belt out "[I Hope I Get It](/wiki/I_Hope_I_Get_It "I Hope I Get
It")", with Cha-ka inexplicably joining in, displaying an impressive singing
voice.

Marshall, Will and Cha-ka celebrate their good fortune. Meanwhile, Holly
pockets a dinosaur egg and learns from a recording left by the long-deceased
Zarn that Enik deceived them and he is actually the one planning to invade
Earth. But she is captured by the Sleestaks to be brought to the Library of
Skulls for judgment. The others save her from being executed for helping Enik,
but the villain—now possessing the amplifier, and mind-controlling the
Sleestaks—leaves them to open a portal to Earth. Marshall pole vaults into
Grumpy's mouth and after removing an intestinal blockage, befriends him. He
joins the others to defeat the Sleestak army and confront Enik. After the
crystal link between the Land of the Lost and Earth is shattered, Enik reveals
the portal will close forever. Thinking fast, Marshall grabs Holly's crystal
and inserts it into the port, knowing that the substitute crystal won't hold
for long. Will chooses to stay behind to live a better life and to prevent
Enik from following Marshall and Holly back to Earth, learning later that
female Pakuni are very attractive.

A triumphant Marshall again appears on _Today_ with the dinosaur egg Holly
brought back to promote his new book _Matt Lauer Can Suck It_. The egg left
behind on the _Today_ set hatches a baby Sleestak, which hisses as the screen
goes black.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

  * [Will Ferrell](/wiki/Will_Ferrell "Will Ferrell") as [Dr. Rick Marshall](/wiki/List_of_Land_of_the_Lost_characters_and_species#The_Marshalls "List of Land of the Lost characters and species"), a renowned paleontologist and author, determined to prove his theory on time warps, thus embarking on a time travel experiment.
  * [Anna Friel](/wiki/Anna_Friel "Anna Friel") as Holly Cantrell, Rick's biggest fan.
  * [Danny McBride](/wiki/Danny_McBride "Danny McBride") as Will Stanton, a gift shop owner who takes Holly and Rick to a tachyon rich cave.
  * [Jorma Taccone](/wiki/Jorma_Taccone "Jorma Taccone") as [Cha-Ka](/wiki/List_of_Land_of_the_Lost_characters_and_species#Ta,_Sa,_and_Cha-Ka "List of Land of the Lost characters and species")
  * [John Boylan](/wiki/John_Boylan_\(Canadian_actor\) "John Boylan \(Canadian actor\)") as [Enik](/wiki/List_of_Land_of_the_Lost_characters_and_species#Enik "List of Land of the Lost characters and species") who plans to invade and conquer Earth, and deceives Rick and the others into believing otherwise; he also controls the Sleestak.
  * [Matt Lauer](/wiki/Matt_Lauer "Matt Lauer") as Himself
  * [Leonard Nimoy](/wiki/Leonard_Nimoy "Leonard Nimoy") as voice of [The Zarn](/wiki/List_of_Land_of_the_Lost_characters_and_species#The_Zarn "List of Land of the Lost characters and species")
  * [Douglas Tait](/wiki/Douglas_Tait_\(stuntman\) "Douglas Tait \(stuntman\)") as [Sleestak](/wiki/Sleestak "Sleestak")

The original actors who played Holly and Will in the TV series, [Kathy
Coleman](/wiki/Kathy_Coleman "Kathy Coleman") and [Wesley
Eure](/wiki/Wesley_Eure "Wesley Eure"), filmed [cameos](/wiki/Cameo_appearance
"Cameo appearance") for the film.[4] However, the final version of the film
cut these scenes.[4] [Bobb'e J. Thompson](/wiki/Bobb%27e_J._Thompson "Bobb'e
J. Thompson"), [Kiernan Shipka](/wiki/Kiernan_Shipka "Kiernan Shipka")
(_uncredited_), [Dylan Sprayberry](/wiki/Dylan_Sprayberry "Dylan Sprayberry"),
and [Sierra McCormick](/wiki/Sierra_McCormick "Sierra McCormick") appeared in
a cameo as Tar Pit Kids and [Raymond Ochoa](/wiki/Raymond_Ochoa "Raymond
Ochoa") as an uncredited boy in a museum.[5]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

Production for the film began on March 4, 2008. Only one week's worth of
filming was shot using a large-scale soundstage with [green
screen](/wiki/Chroma_key "Chroma key") technology.[6] The rest of filming took
place on location in places such as the [Dumont Dunes](/wiki/Dumont_Dunes
"Dumont Dunes") in the [Mojave Desert](/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert"),
the [La Brea Tar Pits](/wiki/La_Brea_Tar_Pits "La Brea Tar Pits") in [Hancock
Park](/wiki/Hancock_Park "Hancock Park"), and [Trona,
California](/wiki/Trona,_San_Bernardino_County,_California "Trona, San
Bernardino County, California").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Marketing")]

The first [trailer](/wiki/Film_trailer "Film trailer") was shown during [Super
Bowl XLIII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIII "Super Bowl XLIII"). [Subway
Restaurants](/wiki/Subway_\(restaurant\) "Subway \(restaurant\)"), which paid
to appear in the film and had cross promotions with (appearing on their cups),
unveiled the second trailer exclusively on their website. [JW Marriott
Hotels](/wiki/JW_Marriott_Hotels "JW Marriott Hotels") and [Pop
Rocks](/wiki/Pop_Rocks "Pop Rocks") also purchased rights to market with film
tie-ins.[7] [Syfy](/wiki/Syfy "Syfy") aired a marathon of [the original
series](/wiki/Land_of_the_Lost_\(1974_TV_series\) "Land of the Lost \(1974 TV
series\)") on Memorial Day in 2009 in coordination with the studio to have
frequent film clips and an interview with [Sid and Marty
Krofft](/wiki/Sid_and_Marty_Krofft "Sid and Marty Krofft").[8] After the
film's release, another marathon aired on
[Chiller](/wiki/Chiller_\(TV_channel\) "Chiller \(TV channel\)") on June 6.
The majority of the first two seasons were also made available on
[Hulu](/wiki/Hulu "Hulu"). Ahead of the film's release, Universal also
released the complete series on DVD; it had previously been released by [Rhino
Home Video](/wiki/Rhino_Home_Video "Rhino Home Video"). The entire series is
also available via download from [Xbox Live](/wiki/Xbox_Live "Xbox Live"). Two
different games were released online to promote the film. "Chakker" was
available to play on the film's official Web site while "Crystal Adventure"
was a free downloadable game for iPhones from Kewlbox. Both
[Subway](/wiki/Subway_\(restaurant\) "Subway \(restaurant\)") and
[MapQuest](/wiki/MapQuest "MapQuest") hosted an online sweepstakes on their
respective Web sites with various movie-related merchandise given away as
prizes. Both sweepstakes ran from May 18 through June 7 of 2009. Ferrell also
appeared on the [season 4](/wiki/List_of_Man_vs._Wild_episodes#Season_4 "List
of Man vs. Wild episodes") premiere of _[Man vs. Wild](/wiki/Man_vs._Wild "Man
vs. Wild")_ , which aired June 2, 2009, to promote the film.

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Music")]

The score to _Land of the Lost_ was composed by [Michael
Giacchino](/wiki/Michael_Giacchino "Michael Giacchino"), who recorded his
score with an 88-piece ensemble of the [Hollywood Studio
Symphony](/wiki/Hollywood_Studio_Symphony "Hollywood Studio Symphony") and a
35-person choir.[9] On May 10, it was also announced by [Dave
Mustaine](/wiki/Dave_Mustaine "Dave Mustaine") on TheLiveLine that some music
from [Megadeth](/wiki/Megadeth "Megadeth") would appear in the film.[10]
Whether this would be music from the new record was not entirely clear,
however during the phone message Mustaine stated that there was new music
playing in the background of the message. However parts of the song "[The
Right to Go Insane](/wiki/The_Right_to_Go_Insane "The Right to Go Insane")",
from the 2009 album _[Endgame](/wiki/Endgame_\(Megadeth_album\) "Endgame
\(Megadeth album\)")_ , can be heard near the end of the film. In the film,
Rick Marshall sings the original _Land of the Lost_ theme and two other tracks
(Tracks 5 and 27) utilize parts of the theme as well., The musical _[A Chorus
Line](/wiki/A_Chorus_Line "A Chorus Line")_ plays a part in the story, and
Ferrell sings [Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher")'s 1998 dance pop hit
"[Believe](/wiki/Believe_\(Cher_song\) "Believe \(Cher song\)")". [Varèse
Sarabande](/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande "Varèse Sarabande") released the
soundtrack album on June 9, 2009 (tracks 30-32 are bonus tracks).

## Differences from original
series[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Differences from original series")]

The film serves as a [parody](/wiki/Parody "Parody") of the original TV
series, similar to _[Starsky& Hutch](/wiki/Starsky_%26_Hutch_\(film\) "Starsky
& Hutch \(film\)")_ and _[The Brady Bunch Movie](/wiki/The_Brady_Bunch_Movie
"The Brady Bunch Movie")_.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In the original series, the main characters
were the father and two children. While the first names remain the same, the
film converts the Holly character into an unrelated research assistant to
allow for more risque humor because she is the main character's love
interest.[11] Will, instead of being a son, is an amusement park operator and
[survivalist](/wiki/Survivalism "Survivalism").[12] Rick Marshall is a
paleontologist in the film, not a park ranger as in the original series. The
film's budget also uses CGI [special effects](/wiki/Special_effects "Special
effects") rather than the puppet and [stop motion](/wiki/Stop_motion "Stop
motion") animation effects that defined the original series."[13] While the
original [Saturday morning](/wiki/Saturday_morning_cartoon "Saturday morning
cartoon") show targeted a child audience, the film was designed for a more
adult audience and includes profanity, sex, and a drug reference, among other
adult-oriented items.[14]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Critical response")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Anna_Friel_TCA_2015.jpg/170px-
Anna_Friel_TCA_2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Anna_Friel_TCA_2015.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Anna_Friel_TCA_2015.jpg "Enlarge")

Despite negative reviews towards the film, [Anna Friel](/wiki/Anna_Friel "Anna
Friel")'s performance was praised by some critics.

[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reports an approval
rating of 26% based on 188 reviews, with an average rating of 4.1/10. The
site's critical consensus reads, "Only loosely based on the original TV
series, _Land of the Lost_ is decidedly less kid-friendly and feels more like
a series of inconsistent sketches than a cohesive adventure comedy."[15] On
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") the film has a weighted average
score of 32 out of 100, based on 32 critics, indicating "generally unfavorable
reviews".[16] Audiences polled by [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore
"CinemaScore") gave the film an average grade of "C+" on an A+ to F scale.[17]

_[The Wall Street Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street
Journal")_ stated that it "isn't worth the celluloid it's printed on",
_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_
remarked that "it leaves you feeling splattered", the New York _[Daily
News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(New_York\) "Daily News \(New York\)")_ called it "a
high-concept disaster", _[The Christian Science
Monitor](/wiki/The_Christian_Science_Monitor "The Christian Science Monitor")_
labeled it "resolutely uninspired", _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ labeled it
"lame", and _[The Miami Herald](/wiki/The_Miami_Herald "The Miami Herald")_
commented that "the whole thing feels at least three summers too stale." A few
critics professed admiration for it, notably [Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert
"Roger Ebert") who gave the film three stars out of four and wrote:

“  | The dinosaurs are so obviously not really there in shots where they menace humans that you could almost say their shots are about how they're not really there. Confronted with such effects, the actors make not the slightest effort to appear terrified, amazed or sometimes even mildly concerned. Some might consider that a weakness. I suspect it is more of a deliberate choice, and I say I enjoyed it.[18] | ”   
---|---|---  
  
_[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(magazine\) "Empire \(magazine\)")_ magazine's Sam Toy
put the film #8 on his best of the year list.[19] On February 1, 2010, the
film led the [30th Golden Raspberry Awards](/wiki/30th_Golden_Raspberry_Awards
"30th Golden Raspberry Awards") with seven nominations (tied with
_[Transformers: Revenge of the
Fallen](/wiki/Transformers:_Revenge_of_the_Fallen "Transformers: Revenge of
the Fallen")_) including [Worst
Picture](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Picture "Golden Raspberry
Award for Worst Picture"), [Worst
Actor](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Actor "Golden Raspberry Award
for Worst Actor") (Ferrell), [Worst
Director](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Director "Golden Raspberry
Award for Worst Director") (Silberling), [Worst
Screenplay](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Screenplay "Golden
Raspberry Award for Worst Screenplay"), [Worst Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Supporting_Actor "Golden
Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actor") (Taccone), [Worst Screen
Couple](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Screen_Couple "Golden Raspberry
Award for Worst Screen Couple") (Ferrell and any co-star, creature or "comic
riff") and [Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or
Sequel](/wiki/Golden_Raspberry_Award_for_Worst_Prequel,_Remake,_Rip-
off_or_Sequel "Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or
Sequel"). The film won the Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or Sequel award.[20]
While at the Savannah Film Festival in 2011, Ron Meyer (president of Universal
Pictures), said that "_Land of the Lost_ was just crap. I mean, there was no
excuse for it. The best intentions all went wrong."[21][22]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Box office")]

On its opening day of June 5, the film was a [box office
flop](/wiki/Box_office_bomb "Box office bomb") by grossing only $7.9 million.
The film performed under expectations in its first weekend in theaters, its
$19 million opening was far less than the expected $30 million. The film's box
office results fell far behind that of the 2009 comedy _[The
Hangover](/wiki/The_Hangover_\(film\) "The Hangover \(film\)")_ , which opened
during the same weekend.[23][24] The film's opening weekend gross was about
two-thirds what Universal reportedly expected to earn.[25] It made $69 million
worldwide.[3] In 2014, the _[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los
Angeles Times")_ listed the film as one of the most expensive box office flops
of all time.[26]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Land_of_the_Lost_\(film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Home media")]

The DVD was released on October 13, 2009, with sales reaching $20,286,563 as
of August 2011.[3]
